theme is really about build on it's about builders and actually what I really love about what's happening in

had the power to build business people analysts start a scientists operations

is what's making it easier and easier and the more people that can build the more innovation occurs within the

you know a lot of it's actually happening right here in Berlin and we're going to touch on some of the local
examples through the rest of the keynote now if you kind of think back what it
was like to be a builder just a few years ago everyone hopefully recommend is the classic interior architecture you
had your browser we had our web server pachi Tomcat as the application server back ended by a
database and you know what back then we would stick logic in all three of those layers we'd have a lot of logic in the
presentation layer we were to have Tomcat doing a lot more than it was really designed for and would have
business logic embedded within that database and it caused all types of issues those of you that have been
trying to migrate away from some of those decisions we made in the past the paying off that technical debt I've got
scar tissue from it and I'm as guilty of that as other people in making some of those decisions it's really hard to do
but if you look at how the architecture has changed to what we call a 21st century architecture it's one of our
customers iRobot you might know them as they're kind of the Roomba vacuum cleaner that goes around for those that
are too lazy to vacuum their own floors but what this diagram is showing you is kind of the registration of a new device
and how it uses a completely serverless architecture to do each step of that
process and at first glance it may actually look that this is more complex there's more components being used in
this simple registration process but the power actually comes from the simplicity
of every one of those single components and so being able to make change within
this is actually far easier and being able to separate the different logic components out the where the business
logic resides the reusability of some of these components for other services this is where the rise of micro services
based architectures really comes into it and all of this is built on standard components and services provided by the
AWS service framework all these services done independently why want to use sqs
simple queuing service for message passing between those services for example api gateway AWS lambda for my
compute functions where i don't have to worry about the virtual machine the operating system patching it i just want
to write my code and deploy it to the cloud and let AWS worry about whether
i'm running that function once a day or 50,000 times a second that's the
power of server list as you go through this now if you're going to be writing
these types of architectures you've got to rethink the deemed hire development cycle now you think about development
cycle it's pretty simple right rewrite code we check in that code we build it
we build the package or the artifact that we're going to deploy which we go put it into a testing environment we run
a whole bunch of tests through it depending on those tests we will then deploy that to production we may have a
be testing Bluegreen deployments to test those functionality and then it goes
into operations when I first started in the industry the bulk of my time was
spent writing code not a lot on the other steps and over time this has
changed you started to think about what about patching is the software gets more
complicated change management especially when you start getting bigger and bigger development teams that may be actually
working all around the world 24 hours a day seven days a week the pace of change
goes up not just deploying code once every three months in a maintenance
window pushing multiple changes per day actually if you look at some of the best
of breed you know kind of born in the cloud companies they are pushing
multiple times per hour that's a completely different way of thinking about the tool chain you got to think
about how do I wrap security around this when it's changing all the time how do I get visibility and transparency as to
what's happening in this environment what about the tool chain itself every
step of this process was often bolted together with completely different components and just trying to get them
to all talk together was complex and hard as well and so we looked at this
and thought well there's things we think we can do to help simplify this for builders and the first step of this is
AWS cloud 9 which is the IDE the integrated development environment that you can use and it allows you to program
and write code directly within the web browser and it's integrated to the AWS platform
now this is really important for example if you're trying to write lambda functions because you want to be able to
write the code and deploy it at the click of a button straight into lambda
debug it within the IDE see what happened and then make changes now as
you do this you may run into a little bit of trouble you may be working on someone else's code and so you can then
collaborate with other developers and have them jump into the IDE and make
changes with you so you can see you can do this collaborative development process you can have a chat window open
so you can be saying look I don't understand what this function is doing your documentation wasn't quite up to
scratch what can we do to do this this is a really powerful feature of modern
development practices it's more than just a single developer working on their own as they go through with this well
what about the next step part of the puzzle if I'm writing the software what about the set of services allow me to
deploy this is where the code star suite of products come into play where for example of code pipeline they can take
your code from any code repository and push that through a deployment cycle into production using code deploy your
code build they can manage that build process for you and code commit which is just one of many different code
repositories you can store this in and all of this is integrated into the greater AWS platform things like I am
for Identity and Access Management control cloud watch cloud trail for changes they're all integrated so all these
other services that you know and love are built into this development cycle you don't need to work out how to
integrate them on your own and then we get to production and the ability to
push it out and again as you push this into production you get all of the power of the services of AWS coming to bear
operations management x-ray which is one of my favorite services that ability in a micro service environment to actually
follow every single transaction and see how it's passed from service to service to service measure the latencies and the
time what happened why did it pause and fail where did it go these are really simple things to do but actually quite
hard to do at scale it's built in to AWS and if you look now at how large the AWS
portfolio of services it's 125 plus services and all this is actually being driven by you the roadmap is driven by
direct feedback from our customers and so over the next two days we get a lot of feedback from summits and if you've
been using the platform you know any suggestions or things you'd like to see that the platform doesn't do grab any of
the AWS staff and have a conversation with us we love hearing feedback from you and this is what drives this continuous innovation as we go through
this I actually think these set of 125 plus services is the best toolkit you
can have as a developer to write applications with and to operate production quality and scale for your
organization's but it's not just about the brother breadth of services now I
don't know how he picks the colors for some of these vendor comparisons some of you might be able to see there's a
hidden meaning here but it's also about the depth of services okay if you look
at for example just object and block key storage capabilities AWS in orange 65
choices you can make for this database engines you can pick from six this is
all about giving you flexibility to be a builder it's all about choice you want to have the choice as to what is best
for your organization what is best for the skill sets within your organization we're not going to dictate to you what
you have to use and so with that to expand upon this in more detail I'll
actually talk about a real example flex boss is a great company their mobility
provider that's changed way over a hundred million people have traveled since they first launched flix bus brand
back in 2013 so talk about what they've been doing it's my absolute pleasure to welcome lars schumer hanko the principal
DevOps engineer for flex mobility to the stage
thank you it was so good morning Berlin
my name is Sascha mischenko and I'm principal DevOps engineer at fixed path and actually my team and I were
responsible to develop the solution I will show you in a bit but first let me
give you introduction to flix path so as gran said we were mobility
providers so we already had more than 100 million customers and last week we
launched our yes business so and now our service is available in 28 countries
with around 1,700 passes on the street we are one of the biggest bus fleets
worldwide but we do not own a single bus so we actually a technology company and
our bus partners are doing the transportation business and now I want to show you a couple of challenges we've
been facing within flix tech the IT organization of flix bus so first of all
we want to support further growth at the moment we have 30 engineering teams and
they need access to infrastructure they need access to service so we need a like
an organizational setup so that the access to that doesn't become a blocker for them on the other side we also want
to scale our organization so we just started 2012 and we've been growing
massively since then so how can we actually stay agile and of course with
all those cloud self services yeah and the teams working in the cloud we really want to make sure that we keep our
infrastructure costs under control so we really need some great cost transparency
what we did as a start into the cloud we created just one AWS account and put all
teams into this account and they were starting using the services however this
was not really scalable yeah so we lost some cost control we lost transparency and we also ended up with some questions
like hey actually who owns a specific ec2 instance we just didn't know anymore so we thought ok we need to rebuild that
and so we were using AWS organizations to create like proper setup for us so we
started mirroring our real organizational structure we're grouping the teams into business domains and as
of now all the teams have two AWS accounts one for the production services and another one for all the testing
services and additionally putting iom and service control policies on top that
really helped us to ensure the security and also the access for the teams to the services but with this AWS organizations
we were also able to like automate it from the beginning because before that you could not really automate account
creation and now we can do that so we can really invest the time into doing that from the beginning and that gave us
really a speed improvement on creating new accounts creating new regions and to
further improve the set up for our other teams moving into the cloud we put
kubernetes and Kafka on top of the set up so it's really an easy start for the teams to do that so what did we achieve
so far all the teams have access to the infrastructure they need they have
access to the services they need they do not have to ask for permissions they can just use it so we have really
happy engineers and we can also like just roll out new business features we
can test out new business ideas much much much faster and we're also able to
scale our infrastructure so all the changes to our base set up it's just a
change in the configuration there is no manual work anymore so just to give you an example how did it work for us for
the u.s. business we launched the infrastructure in just one day which was just not possible before before we took
like much much longer and that was a really great achievement and we also like it shift our cross transparency we
wanted to have so with the organizational like mirroring within AWS
organizations we can break down the cost to services we can group them by business domain so we can give everybody also the
business full transparency about the infrastructure costs they really in use
at the moment so as a summary we are clearly quite happy with the setup
however having now 60 AWS accounts there are also like a lot of new challenges so
for example when we have applications running in different accounts how can we really make sure that they have a proper
communication between the applications at the moment we use peering but we already know that there are limitations
so we're really looking into like a next
thing which is AWS private link we already tested it out and it can really help us doing the cross application
cross account communication in the right way and as we are already running a lot of kubernetes clusters on AWS we were of
course really excited about eks because that will allow us to like put less effort into the infrastructure and focus
more on product delivery and as it's generally available since yesterday have we really looking forward to test it out
very soon so that's it from my side if
you haven't tried out flix bus yet download the app and probably you book your next trip with us thank you for
your attention and enjoy the remaining summit see ya

is evolving to so with that it's my absolute pleasure to welcome Ralph to the stage Thank You Glenn
thanks a lot clan and good morning they come some AWS summit Carmel einavofer
for a full spa VM but therefore here's AA kind of video all Oceanian and with that I asked Lance said I do want to
start this session with a bit of history on machine learning both in academia
I've been spending 25 years and at Amazon and one of the interesting things
is that as an academic field machine learning is really young it's just 25
years or it's just 50 years old and 50 years isn't very long and in academia and even more interesting is
that judging how popular is today and how much aspects of everyday is life it
is affecting for the first 40 year of its of its existence the field was more of a stepchild and if you studied
machine learning back in the mid 90s when I started it was a very small crowd
that had the passion that foresaw a world that we have today but machine learning is used when you leave the
house when you go at work when you come back everywhere the whole time and as a
result the set of domain experts in this field is really small people that have decades of experience
but the importance of machine learning is very high and we observe this and we
notices in Amazon early on and the way we solve this is we didn't couldn't accelerate time but we took the science
and we decided we we want to codify we want to put the insides from the from the scientific field into our the
algorithms into code into libraries and services that could be reused and we did
that for some of the applications that are more prominent that yet many of you have seen so for example many in the
audience have probably used Amazon to shop and have seen people who bought this also bought that that's an
application of machine learning in fact one where we helped set and define the field another one that many of you've
tried or even possesses our speech recognition in Alexa so the detection of
speech the generation of speech extractions of facts from the from the web and the
the answering the questions that's machine learning at work or the Amazon go store where we make it possible to go
shop and have no checkout that's an application of computer vision and machine learning or if you soon our
delivery with prime air that's an application where you see machine learning in action but if you look below
the surface you see there is hundreds hundreds of application where we use
machine learning where we use libraries and of basic building blocks to allow
our retail customers to have better inventory management because in lower prices because we predict the demand of
a fashion of books of kitchenware of of consumables every single day in order to
stock right or where we take our catalog and we fill the quality of the data and the catalog in automatically and help
our vendors to have more accurate entries of their products or we help our
sellers over our two million sellers both the prevention of fraud and the and
help if they look for help with their with the products they sell them with their customers or we help people our
content creators and re-indexing books and US customers experiences x-ray and
these are applications of machine learning and the building blocks of the science codified in in libraries and
services that it doesn't meet the eye directly but they're very impactful and
we've learnt many lessons of what those building blocks are in fact what we've seen is and if you make these building
blocks available many employees not just a scientist not just the engineers we have analysts who automatically build
models with the tools we have to clean and to curate the catalog of of sellers
in a particular region or that generated models for for lead generation and the
sales and there's three lessons we've learned as Amazon over the last twenty years that are necessary for machine
learning to really root and and sustain and generate business value in an
application so the first lesson that we've learned is that data keeps increasing so any codification any
implementation of machine learning primitives whether it's time serious classification its
parameter optimization it's image recognition it has to scale to an
ever-growing amount of data so the notion of cloud scale in data as well as in in computer
is important the second thing we've learned is it has to be extensible so people started inventing albums in the
80s but even today every month our scientists and our engineers invent new
algorithms so any framework that we have needs to have the ability that's extensible there's no fixed and finite
an enclosed set of algorithms that really solve the problems in everyday life and the last one and that's
probably one of the most important months we've learned that it has to become accessible not to this small set of experts who had you know who foresaw
some future 25 years ago it has to be accessible to the scientists that have used it for decades to the developers
that used it for last decade but then also to analyst and every employee in the company and this accessibility is
really what unlock the value for us at Amazon of machine learning as a as a
science and in order to talk about how to realize that for you with infinite
data I want to bring back Glenn through stage Thank You Ralph so Ralph you know
we had you a year ago on stage thank you kind of curious what do you say is the
being the biggest change in the last year for you in the world of machine learning yeah so one of the things that
people often feel is machining is a bit of a magic dust you Sparkle on top of your application and it becomes an
unlock value but the reality is that machine running extracts the magic dust out of data and if you and data keeps
increasing in complexity and in size because of you know the Internet of Things and sensors that are available at
all you know all company sizes today so both the amount of data and the quality
of that become one of the most important drivers of making the value of machinery actually work and that's the increase of
that has actually been one of the biggest change in the last 12 months I think that volume dollars is gonna keep getting bigger and bigger it does
because people invent more sensors thank you very much for joining us great to
have a they said you know Berlin is leading the way with this you know there's a lot of AI ml experts coming
out of Berlin which is fantastic to see so you think about infinite data really
it's never been easier or cheaper to collect and store data in some ways there's no excuse not to store something
as long as you're feeling within you know compliance and regulatory needs that you have within your organization's
but this is the key to starting with machine learning is having this data
ontap and you know there's a couple ways to do this one is you have new data which is pretty easy right it's coming
from new applications that have already been deployed in the clouds so the obvious place to store that is in things
like s3 for example or now in databases but what about your existing data how do
we migrate that to the cloud you can use things like snowball you can use Direct Connect you can even venues in the US
for example snowmobile which is a big semi trailer for the storage you just park outside your data center and it
vacuums up the data and moves it to a region but as this moves across the next
step is well what are the algorithms I want to apply to my data that's going to
generate the mod that I then use to get the insights into what questions I'm trying to ask of this
starter whether it be fraud management prediction models image classification natural language processing but all is
based on this kind of three common building blocks the data may be training data in a series of natural language
processing for example or it could be real time transactional data going through a retail e-commerce provider
looking at for example buying behavior and sales prediction models it doesn't matter what is batch real-time they all
follow this kind of data I algorithm model approach and as you have that
model you feed new data into that model which allows you for example to have a prediction and often that model is
actually creating new data itself which is in feeds back into this cycle this is why you see this explosion in an
